properties.Name: British Pub
properties.description: Approximate locations for where we stopped for lunch the first day. Based on the clientele, it seemed like a pretty standard stop for the tour groups.

properties.Name: Russian Market
properties.description: The morning we arrived, the group spent time walking around the Russian market. There were plenty of vendors selling street food and souvenirs as well as regular market necessities.

properties.Name: Sha Coffee
properties.description: The imposing outside is deceiving, but inside is a really cute and hip coffee shop! Our tour guide, Anna, recommended it.

properties.Name: Inspiration Alley
properties.description: This outdoor park is full of monuments to famous Islamic scholars and thinkers.

properties.Name: Tumar House
properties.description: I'm not sure if this is the right point. We had lunch the second day at Tumar Pub/Old English Tumar House. It was so charming and cozy with stacks of books surrounding many of the tables.

properties.Name: Panorama terrace
properties.description: The group had our goodbye dinner here. The view overlooks many of the Ashgabat monuments, and at night, you can see the city light up.

properties.Name: Kow Ata Underground Sulfur Spring
properties.description: We had a good time relaxing in the sulfur water, curing all of our ailments--at least according to the sign at the entrance. The walk down through the cave is steep, so walk carefully! Our guide said it can get really busy during the weekend, but we had it to ourselves for most of the time. There is a shallow ledge that I spent most of my time in, but the water can get deep. Bring a floaty or maybe some diving flippers if you're adventurous.

properties.Name: Darvaza Gas Crater
properties.description: The highlight and the main reason for going on the trip! The crater has been burning off natural gas since 1971, when Soviet geologists were searching for oil. You can walk as close as you'd like to the pit. Our guide told us a local man once fell asleep near the edge and rolled in while asleep, but don't worry, he survived! Read more on wikipedia: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Darvaza_gas_crater

properties.Name: Campsite
properties.description: Our campsite for the night was about 250 meters away from the gas crater. We stayed in tents, but one of the drivers had a yurt built in case the weather turned bad.

properties.Name: Crater #2
properties.description: This crater had a bubbling mud pit and a small fire burning.

properties.Name: Crater #1
properties.description: One the way to Darvaza there are a couple other craters, or sinkholes, that we stopped to see. This one was filled with water.

properties.Name: Village stop
properties.description: On the drive back from Darvaza Gas Crater, we stopped a village to see what life is like outside of Ashgabat. We saw some camels and could hear children playing in the schoolyard nearby.

properties.Name: Yyldyz Hotel
properties.description: Shaped like a teardrop, this building looks similar to the Flame Towers in Baku.

properties.Name: Wedding Palace
properties.description: The only place in Ashgabat to get married--and divorced!

properties.Name: Halk Hakydasy Memorial Complex
properties.description: This nice park has monuments in remembrance of World War 2 and the earthquake that devastated the city in 1948

properties.Name: Bitaraplyk Binasy
properties.description: Known in English as the Neutrality Monument, this tower has a cool elevator that goes up the side of the legs like a funicular.

properties.Name: Independence Monument
properties.description: The monument is right across from the national library, which was stunning and of course my favorite part about this stop on the city tour.
